candidates.title: Did a Pink Volcano Erupt in New Zealand?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A video shows a pink volcano erupting in New Zealand.
Rating:
False
About this rating
A video purportedly showing bright fuschia smoke billowing from a volcano frequently appears on social media, along with a claim that it shows an actual "pink volcano" erupting in New Zealand:
Pink eruption of the volcano in New Zealand
The video does not explain what chemical process might turn smoke or steam this particular shade (although with the proper dyes, it is possible to turn smoke into a veritable rainbow), but it isn't particularly relevant anyway; this video does not depict an actual volcanic eruption.
The "pink volcano" video was created by artist Filip Hodas, and was originally shared to his Facebook page in December 2016. Hodas posted the video to Instagram (with tags such as #3D, #photoshop, #render, and #animation), and provided extra insight into how the video was created in response to a query on Facebook:
pretty much! depends on what I need. In this case I layered few planes with wm maps on top of each other and added a lot of zdepth fog to blend it in.
No records of volcanos emitting bright pink smoke exist, except those created by digital artists.
candidates.description: Video purportedly showing oddly-colored smoke and steam rising from a eruption was digitally manipulated.

result.explanation: The provided evidence directly contradicts the news caption. Snopes, a fact-checking website, explicitly debunks the claim of a pink volcano erupting in New Zealand.  It states that the video showing pink smoke is digitally manipulated and created by an artist, Filip Hodas, and that no records exist of volcanoes emitting bright pink smoke.

final_result.explanation: The caption claims that the image depicts an actual "pink volcano" erupting in New Zealand.  Both internal and external checks strongly refute this claim. The internal check points out the image's ambiguity; while it shows a pink and purple smoke plume resembling a volcanic eruption, there is no evidence within the image itself to confirm its location as New Zealand.  The external check provides compelling evidence from Snopes, a reputable fact-checking website. Snopes definitively debunks the claim, citing that the image is digitally manipulated artwork created by artist Filip Hodas.  The fact-checking website further states there are no documented instances of volcanoes producing bright pink smoke.  The high confidence score (10) from the external check stems from Snopes's thorough investigation and its established reputation for accuracy in verifying online claims. The internal check, while unable to definitively confirm or deny the location, aligns with the external finding by highlighting the absence of verifiable evidence within the image. The combined evidence strongly suggests the caption is out of context, as the image does not represent a real pink volcano erupting in New Zealand. There is no conflict between the internal and external checks; both support the conclusion that the caption is false.  The high confidence score reflects the strong supporting evidence from the external check and the complementary nature of the internal assessment.
